headline: Ask HN: How vulnerable is Russian military hardware to hacking?
description:
If there's one thing I've learned from listening to the Darknet Diaries podcast, it's that almost any important piece of computerised equipment is vulnerable to sabotage. Even obscure industrial controllers in oil refineries can be damaged if you're familiar with how they work, and you're creative enough to nudge them into an unsafe state.

So when I see that 64km military convoy outside Kyiv...

...full of heavily armoured vehicles and brutal looking military gear...

...I naturally wonder: how much of this kit is computerised? How vulnerable is it to malicious code?

Instead of taking down websites, could Anonymous reasonably develop a 0-day for the 9K720 short-range tactical ballistic missile system? Does the Koalitsiya-SV 152mm self-propelled howitzer even have Wi-Fi?

This is just a random Sunday morning thought, but I'd be interested if anybody can enlighten me on any of this.
headline_zh-Hans: Ask HN: 俄罗斯军事硬件对黑客攻击的脆弱性如何？
headline_zh-Hant: Ask HN: 俄羅斯軍事硬件對黑客攻擊的脆弱性如何？
description_zh-Hans:
如果说我从收听《暗网日记》播客中学到了一件事，那就是几乎所有重要的计算机化设备都容易遭到破坏。即使是炼油厂里不起眼的工业控制器也可以被破坏，如果你熟悉它们的工作原理，而且你有足够的创造力将它们推到不安全的状态。

因此，当我看到基辅城外64公里的军事车队......

......充满了重型装甲车和看起来很残忍的军事装备......

......我自然会想：这些装备有多少是计算机化的？它在恶意代码面前有多大的脆弱性？

与其瘫痪网站，匿名者是否可以合理地为9K720短程战术弹道导弹系统开发一个0-day？Koalitsiya-SV 152毫米自行榴弹炮甚至有Wi-Fi吗？

这只是周日早上的一个随机想法，但如果有人能在这些方面启发我，我将很感兴趣。
